lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a video and answer comprehension questions about clothes in Ghana.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before the video, ask: “What clothes do you think people wear in Ghana?” Write guesses, then confirm during listening.
stretchStrategies: Family Web Debate – After watching the video, groups make a “family web” chart comparing Sam’s family and their own. Then discuss: “Why are families important?” Groups write one reason on a sticky note, place on class board, and vote on strongest ideas. Blends listening, social studies, and critical thinking.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can explain how clothing in Ghana is similar to or different from their own clothing.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Compare clothing using a T-chart: Ghana vs. Vietnam. Ask: “What’s similar?” “What’s different?” Use SB visuals.
stretchStrategies: Family Web Debate – After watching the video, groups make a “family web” chart comparing Sam’s family and their own. Then discuss: “Why are families important?” Groups write one reason on a sticky note, place on class board, and vote on strongest ideas. Blends listening, social studies, and critical thinking.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can politely listen to others and share opinions about what to do with old clothes.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Discussion) Ask: “What can we do with old clothes?” Brainstorm ideas on the board (give, reuse, recycle) and vote as a class.
stretchStrategies: Family Web Debate – After watching the video, groups make a “family web” chart comparing Sam’s family and their own. Then discuss: “Why are families important?” Groups write one reason on a sticky note, place on class board, and vote on strongest ideas. Blends listening, social studies, and critical thinking.

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.
VYL: many words starting in sibilants prove extremely difficult (shirt, shorts, socks, shoes). Plurals for singular items (trousers, shorts)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
